discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Revenue generation: Restoring functions that are critical to generating revenue should be a high priority, as the longer these functions are down, the greater the financial impact on the company.
 Supply chain issues: If the outage affects the company's ability to receive or ship goods, it could impact the company's ability to meet customer demand. Restoring functions that are critical to the supply chain should be a high priority.
 Scheduled impacts to future projects: If the outage will have a significant impact on upcoming projects or initiatives, it is important to prioritize the restoration of these functions to minimize disruption.
 Warm-site operations: While warm-site operations can be used as a temporary solution to maintain some business operations, they should not be the primary focus for restoration efforts.

Selected Answer: B
B. Revenue generation

Explanation:
When determining the priorities for restoring mission-essential functions, the impact on revenue generation is a critical consideration. If a retailer's key systems are down, the ability to generate revenue (e.g., through sales, processing transactions, or maintaining customer interactions) should be restored as quickly as possible. The financial impact of prolonged outages can be significant, so prioritizing functions that directly impact revenue is vital for the businessâ€™s survival and long-term viability.

Selected Answer: B
When setting priorities for the restoration of mission-essential functions that would take more than seven days to recover in the event of an outage, revenue generation should be considered. The priority should be given to restoring those functions first, which are generating revenue for the organization. This will help minimize the financial impact of the outage. The other options may also be considered, but they are not directly related to the prioritization of mission-essential functions during an outage.

Can't we rule out C, warm site operations, since it can take around a week to become operational at a warm site? A hot site would be more suitable if a 7 day recovery time for critical business functions is too long.

comments.content:
I'm tired with the people who answered by cheap AI like "Mr_BuCk3th34D" and "p1s3c" did.
From my perspective, the question is asking about the priorities and C is a part of the overall recovery strategy rather than a factor for setting immediate restoration priorities.
Supply chain issues affect the availability of products and the ability to fulfill orders, usually part of a broader consideration related to operational capabilities so it is not priority here.
Future project schedules are important for long-term planning but are secondary to the immediate need, not the first priority.
Revenue generation is the lifeblood of any business, especially an online retailer, directly impact the ability to process transactions, manage orders, and maintain the online storefront should be prioritized to ensure that the company continues to generate income. This is critical for both short-term recovery and long-term sustainability

questions.question_text: A BIA of a popular online retailer identified several mission-essential functions that would take more than seven days to recover in the event of an outage. Which of the following should be considered when setting priorities for the restoration of these functions?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Hackers have access the software repository to change the package, which is automatically published on the website, they didn't compromise the website itself to change the checksum value. 

Distributing the software via a third-party repository (option A) or emailing the software link to all customers (option C) would not necessarily ensure that customers are downloading the official software released by the company.

Selected Answer: A
If they can change a file in the repository, then they can change the SHA checksum listed for verification. A trusted third-party provider should be used to host the software.

Selected Answer: D
D. Display the SHA checksum on the website.

Explanation:
Displaying the SHA checksum (a cryptographic hash value) on the website allows users to verify the integrity of the software they are downloading. The checksum can be calculated for the software package that has been officially released by the company. Users can then compare the checksum of the downloaded file with the one displayed on the website. If the checksums match, it confirms that the downloaded file is authentic and hasn't been tampered with.

Selected Answer: D
Definitely D

I believe the question is focused around integrity ("ensure the software the users download is the official software") and even though outsourcing to a 3rd party repository might be a good option, the only answer dealing with integrity is displaying the SHA checksum, regardless of how "weak" this method may be.

Selected Answer: A
If you can't do security properly and it is a recurring problem, outsource hosting the application to a trusted 3rd party that has the security you don't. 
The SHA is a great method and the standard when you aren't always being hacked. The key phrase I see is "automatically publish to website" This means that the hackers don't even need access to the website to change the SHA posted because automation in place will do it for you. :)

Source:
Verifying each answer against Chat GPT, my experience, other test banks, a written book, and weighing in the discussion from all users to create a 100% accurate guide for myself before I take the exam. (It isn't easy because of the time needed, but it is doing my diligence)

Selected Answer: D
D seems the most logical to me

Selected Answer: D
Customers can compare the SHA checksum displayed on the website with the SHA checksum of the downloaded file to ensure that the software is the official software released by the company.
A is correct

questions.question_text: A software development company makes its software version available to customers from a web portal. On several occasions, hackers were able to access the software repository to change the package that is automatically published on the website. Which of the following would be the technique to ensure the software the users download is the official software released by the company?

choices.A: Distribute the software via a third-party repository.
choices.D: Display the SHA checksum on the website.
choices.B: Close the web repository and deliver the software via email.
choices.C: Email the software link to all customers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Embedded cryptoprocessor (option B): An embedded cryptoprocessor is a specialized chip that is designed to perform cryptographic operations, such as encrypting and decrypting data, generating and verifying digital signatures, and generating and storing cryptographic keys. By installing an HSM with an embedded cryptoprocessor in the mobile device, the organization can ensure that sensitive data is processed and stored in a secure manner.

Hardware-backed public key storage (option C): A hardware-backed keystore is a secure storage area that is physically isolated from the rest of the device and is designed to store cryptographic keys. By using an HSM with hardware-backed public key storage, the organization can ensure that public keys are stored in a secure and tamper-resistant manner, which is important for ensuring the security of digital certificates and other sensitive data.

comments.content: they asked for features. HSM is a cryptoprocessor and that is its feature it can carry cryptographic operations.
if HSM is a cryptoprocessor itself, why built in cryptoprocessor would be useful?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Not only another site has the answer BC as correct, also it clearly stated the chip uses HSM not TPM. For more details i used the linked below to tell the difference and also explain why BC is correct
https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/88744/what-are-the-differences-between-tpm-and-hsm

Selected Answer: BC
B. Embedded cryptoprocessor
C. Hardware-backed public key storage

Explanation:
B. Embedded cryptoprocessor: A cryptoprocessor is a specialized processor designed for performing cryptographic operations securely. By embedding it in a microSD HSM, the device can securely perform encryption, decryption, and key generation without exposing sensitive data to the rest of the mobile device. This enhances the security of corporate resources accessed remotely, which aligns with the organization's goal of protecting sensitive data.

C. Hardware-backed public key storage: Storing public keys and private keys in hardware (such as an HSM) ensures that the keys are securely stored and protected from being extracted or tampered with. This is crucial for the secure access to corporate resources, as it allows the mobile device to authenticate and establish secure communications using cryptographic techniques, but without risking key exposure to malware or unauthorized access.

Selected Answer: BC
Source:
Verifying each answer against Chat GPT, my experience, other test banks, a written book, and weighing in the discussion from all users to create a 100% accurate guide for myself before I take the exam. (It isn't easy because of the time needed, but it is doing my diligence)
The correct answers are: Embedded cryptoprocessor, Decentralized key management
BC is the correct answer

Selected Answer: BC
B and C are the most important features of an HSM

questions.question_text: An organization decided to begin issuing corporate mobile device users microSD HSMs that must be installed in the mobile devices in order to access corporate resources remotely. Which of the following features of these devices MOST likely led to this decision? (Choose two.)

A company recently acquired a SaaS provider and needs to integrate its platform into the company's existing infrastructure without impact to the customer's experience. The SaaS provider does not have a mature security program. A recent vulnerability scan of the SaaS provider's systems shows multiple critical vulnerabilities attributed to very old and outdated OSs. Which of the following solutions would prevent these vulnerabilities from being introduced into the company's existing infrastructure?

choices.A: Segment the systems to reduce the attack surface if an attack occurs.
choices.B: Migrate the services to new systems with a supported and patched OS.
choices.D: Install anti-malware, HIPS, and host-based firewalls on each of the systems.
choices.C: Patch the systems to the latest versions of the existing OSs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I agree that this question is poorly worded. But if we just segment the network and leave the critical vulnerabilities alone, then there will be an impact to the customers when those vulnerabilities are exploited. Migrate to latest and greatest and call it a day.

Selected Answer: B
We have to prevent the introduction as well as "NOT impact customers experience." A. would not prevent, only mitigate. C. Would impact the customers experience due to reboots. D. would most definitely cause interruptions. 

B. makes the most sense and I believe what they are trying to suggest here is that by "migrating" we are doing some sort of no downtime blue/green scenario where the service does not go down and impact customer experience.

Selected Answer: A
I'm going with A because the question reads "without impact to the customer's experience". I complexly agree that B is the best choice, but this would impact the users during migration. There will be a downtime. If we segment, they wouldn't notice any impact

comments.content: nevermind go with B lol A would allow for the vulnerabilities to be introduced into the network. I hate this question

On the other hand the person who wrote the question could be thinking, the application experience doesn't change from the underlying OS changes. Sometimes the lack of information and wording on these questions drive me nuts.

I'm still torn on this one, lol. I think B is the best answer but it's like you have to read the mind of the person who wrote the question. Updates can and do often impact applications! I've seen it many times myself. Patch rollback is not an uncommon thing.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Given the wording of the question, I'd go with A. It would prevent impact to customer given that updates to the OS could certainly impact the customer's experience if the SaaS application is affected negatively by the updates. It also completely shields the existing systems by completely segmenting the new SaaS servers. 

B is a good answer, I just don't think it fits best with the wording of the question.

comments.content:
They acquired the SaaS provider, so we can assume that this company is also a cloud provider. 

If they were not a cloud provider, I'd assume insurance, or multi-cloud provider option would be available. It seems that rather than having a cloud solution, I'm going to assume they are the cloud solution.
I would agree with this, I will lean towards B
I meant they are now responsible...
You can't update the OS for a SaaS provider but the provider themselves can. Because the company acquired the SaaS provider, they are not responsible for updating the underlying OS.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
SaaS guys! You can not update the OS for a SaaS provider. Best answer here is A, is it a good answer, no, but it is the best answer.

it is choice A. Firstly, because you do not want to impact customer experience. All other options would impact customer experience. Secondly, you do NOT patch OS and systems in a SaaS partnership. That is the SaaS providers job, so that would make the other options wrong

Selected Answer: B
UPDATE them! duh! LMAO
Source:
Verifying each answer against Chat GPT, my experience, other test banks, a written book, and weighing in the discussion from all users to create a 100% accurate guide for myself before I take the exam. (It isn't easy because of the time needed, but it is doing my diligence)

Selected Answer: B
B. Migrate the services to new systems with a supported and patched OS.

The SaaS provider's critical vulnerabilities attributed to very old and outdated OSs can pose significant security risks and need to be addressed before integrating its platform into the company's existing infrastructure. Migrating the services to new systems with a supported and patched OS is the best solution to prevent these vulnerabilities from being introduced into the company's existing infrastructure. Segmentation can limit the attack surface but does not address the underlying issue of outdated OSs. Patching the systems to the latest versions of the existing OSs may not be feasible, depending on the level of obsolescence of the existing OSs. Installing anti-malware, HIPS, and host-based firewalls can help mitigate some risks, but it is not a comprehensive solution and may not address all the issues with outdated OSs.
B is the correct answer

questions.question_text:
A company was recently infected by malware. During the root cause analysis, the company determined that several users were installing their own applications.
To prevent further compromises, the company has decided it will only allow authorized applications to run on its systems. Which of the following should the company implement?

discussion.content:
I think the answer is B

Allow List, Permit List

An Allow List also know as a "Permit List" or (deprecated White List) is a list of entities that are considered trustworthy and are granted access or privileges. They can be used to authenticate users managing Firewalls as these IP addressess can be allowed to manage this Firewall. Other times Allow List/Permit List allow users to "permit" certain software (applications) to run on a computer system while all others are blocked.

comments.content: I agree. Think this is just a question to force CompTIA's own made-up terminology down peoples' throats.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Signing won't do anything without something to permit and deny based on the signed publisher. I work with application control and I never hear it referred to as "permit listing". I think the answer's wording is bad but I think this is the right choice.

Selected Answer: D
permit only what is allowed = Whitelisting
permit listing = Application White listing/Application Control

Source:
Verifying each answer against Chat GPT, my experience, other test banks, a written book, and weighing in the discussion from all users to create a 100% accurate guide for myself before I take the exam. (It isn't easy because of the time needed, but it is doing my diligence)

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer
D is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
Code signing is designed to provide a mechanism by which software can be
verified to come from a trusted source. The presence of a code signature does
not offer guarantees of code quality as it simply validates the originator. Verifying
the originator of software can help measure its trustworthiness and can be used
as a means to restrict software from running on a host, for example blocking
any unsigned software from running or specifying that only software from a predefined
set of signors can be used.

comments.content: I would like to officially change my answer to D.. sheesh..
The Official CompTIA CASP+ Student Guide (Exam CAS-004) p 242

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Permit listing or allow list (former whitelist)
D is the correct answer

comments.content: My problem with "signing" is that it is still has the potential of unwanted software. Like installing a signed app that comes bundled with McAfee (trellix) whatever they are called now. Which isn't technically malware, but it could interfere with the enterprises AV solution. Which is why I believe D is the answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
signing - signed application code
From Official Cert Guide-
Unsigned applications are code that cannot be verified to be what it purports to be or to be free of malware. While many unsigned applications present absolutely no security issues, most enterprises wisely choose to forbid their installation. MDM software and security settings in the devices themselves can be used to prevent installation of unsigned apps.

Selected Answer: D
D is my answer

Selected Answer: D
Allow list, also known as a Permit List or (deprecated: White List),
this list will only allow certain software to run on a computer and block any other application from being installed

Whitelisting is a network security approach that blocks resource access to all but a select few trusted entities. Also referred to as permit lists, allowlists, or passlists, whitelists can contribute to your access control strategy by making highly sensitive resources harder for adversaries to penetrate. - google
Code signing occurs when code creators digitally sign executables and scripts so that the user installing the code can be assured that it comes from the verified author.
They are talking code signing

Selected Answer: D
This answer make no sense and i can't get a valid definition for them. My best guess is permit listing is the same as white listing, if it is then D is the correct answer since is exactly what the question is asking. If someone has some ideas as to what application signing is please share
